abstract cumulative_density(parameters: [<class 'float'>])[source]

Returns the cumulative distribution at parameters between 0 and 1.

abstract interval_density(parameters: [<class 'float'>])[source]

Returns the cumulative density (integral of the interpolated curve) between n parameter pairs as intervals (i.e. returns n-1 results)

Parameters:

parameters – Any set of floats between 0 and 1

Returns:

List of floats representing the cumulative density of that interval.

If the input parameters span 0 to 1, the sum of the interval densities will reach 1.

sample(size: int = 1)[source]
type: Type
class rangekeeper.distribution.PERT(peak: float = 0.5, weighting: float = 4.0, minimum: float = 0.0, maximum: float = 1.0, generator: Optional[Generator] = None)[source]

Bases: Form

A continuous distribution that is controlled by the placement and weighting of the mode (peak) value. It produces similar distributions to the Normal (Gaussian) distribution within a specified domain. Its cumulative distribution function (CDF) curve is a classic ‘s-curve’.

Peak must be between 0 and 1. Weighting must be >= 0. Standard weighting is 4.

Specifically, it is a Beta Distribution extended to specified domain, with the mean (μ) constrained so that μ = (a + Ɣ*b + c) / (Ɣ + 2), where a and c are the limits (0 and 1 in this formulation), b is the mode (peak value), and Ɣ is a weighting factor for the mode.

This function is built from the formulation in Tensorflow: https://github.com/tensorflow/probability/blob/master/tensorflow_probability/python/distributions/pert.py

class rangekeeper.distribution.Triangular(lower: float = 0.0, upper: float = 1.0, mode: float = 0.5, generator: Optional[Generator] = None)[source]

Bases: Form

A continuous probability distribution with lower limit a, upper limit b and mode c, where a < b and a ≤ c ≤ b.

class rangekeeper.distribution.Uniform(lower: float = 0.0, range: float = 1.0, generator: Optional[Generator] = None)[source]

Bases: Form

For default arguments, this is a continuous, uniform distribution between 0 and 1, such the cumulative distribution reaches 1. (For uniform distribution, this means the density is continuously 1).

For specified arguments, this distribution is constant between lower, and lower + range.

cumulative_density(parameters: [<class 'float'>]) → [<class 'float'>][source]

Returns the cumulative distribution at parameters between 0 and 1.

Parameters:

parameters – Any set of floats between 0 and 1

List of floats representing the cumulative density of that interval.

If the input parameters span 0 to 1, the sum of the interval densities will reach 1.

rangekeeper.extrapolation module

class rangekeeper.extrapolation.Compounding(rate: float)[source]

Bases: Form

rate: float

An exponentially growing (compounding) or decaying projection at a specified rate per period. To calculate the factor, the projection is modelled as an exponential function of (1 + rate) ** period

terms(sequence: RangeIndex) → [<class 'float'>][source]

Returns the multiplicative factors of the projection’s form at each value in the sequence.

class rangekeeper.extrapolation.Form[source]

Bases: object

abstract terms(sequence: RangeIndex) → [<class 'float'>][source]

Returns the set of terms that define the projection’s form at each value in the sequence.

type: Type

A specified methodology, logic, or algorithm for extrapolating a value to a sequence.

class rangekeeper.extrapolation.Recurring[source]

Bases: StraightLine

class rangekeeper.extrapolation.StraightLine(slope: float)[source]

Bases: Form

slope: float

A constant-change (linearly growing (or decaying)) projection form, originating from an initial value. To calculate the factor, the projection is modelled as a linear function of (slope * period) + 1

terms(sequence: RangeIndex) → [<class 'float'>][source]

Returns the additive terms to the projection at each value in the sequence.

STRAIGHT_LINE = 'Straight Line'

Generate a Flow from a projection of a value, with an optional timing offset in the application of the projection to the value. (i.e., the projection factors/densities begin before or after the index does)

Also accepts a Distribution as a value input, which will be randomly sampled.

rangekeeper.periodicity.duration(start_date: Timestamp, end_date: Timestamp, period_type: Type, inclusive: bool = False) → int[source]

Returns the whole integer (i.e. no remainder) number of periods between given dates. If inclusive is True, the end_date is included in the calculation.

Returns a pd.PeriodIndex with periods offset by given number of periods (of type given by the index)

rangekeeper.periodicity.period_index(include_start: Timestamp, period_type: Type, bound: Optional[Union[Timestamp, int]] = None) → PeriodIndex[source]

Returns a pd.PeriodIndex from a start date with periods of given duration. Either an end date, or number of periods must be given to bound the sequence.

Parameters:

  • include_start – pd.Timestamp start date

  • period_type – Period frequency

  • bound – A terminating condition; either a pd.Timestamp end date or a (integer) number of periods

rangekeeper.periodicity.periods_per_year(period_type: Type) → int[source]
rangekeeper.periodicity.single_period_index(period: Period) → PeriodIndex[source]
rangekeeper.periodicity.to_datestamps(period_index: PeriodIndex, end: bool = True) → DatetimeIndex[source]

Returns a pd.DatetimeIndex from a pd.PeriodIndex with Datetimes being Dates :param end: If True, the end of the period is used. If False, the start of the period is used.

classmethod from_date_sequence(names: [str], dates: [pd.Timestamp]) → [Span][source]

Create a set of Spans from a sequence of dates. Note: dates list length must be 1 longer than names :param names: :type names: :param dates: :type dates: :return: :rtype:

classmethod from_num_periods(name: str, date: Timestamp, period_type: Type, num_periods: int) → Span[source]

Create a Span from a date with a set number of periods of specified type. If the number of periods is negative, the Span will end on the date specified. If the number of periods is positive, the Span will start on the date specified.

classmethod from_num_periods_sequence(names: [str], period_type: rk.periodicity.Type, durations: [int], start_date: pd.Timestamp) → [Span][source]

Create a set of Spans from a sequence of durations of specified period type :param names: :type names: :param period_type: :type period_type: :param durations: :type durations: :param start_date: :type start_date: :return: :rtype:

classmethod merge(name: str, spans: [Span]) → Span[source]

Merge a set of Spans into a single Span

name: str = None

A Span is a pd.Interval of pd.Timestamps that bound its start and end dates

shift(num_periods: int, period_type: Type, bound: str = 'end', name: Optional[str] = None) → Span[source]

Shift the Span’s bounds by a specified period increment

Parameters:

  • num_periods – The number of periods to shift the bounds

  • period_type – The period type of the shift

  • bound – The bound to shift. Options are ‘start’, ‘end’, or ‘both’

start_date: Timestamp
to_index(period_type: Type) → PeriodIndex[source]

Module contents

rangekeeper.update_class(main_class=None, exclude=('__module__', '__name__', '__dict__', '__weakref__'))[source]

Class decorator. Adds all methods and members from the wrapped class to main_class

Args: - main_class: class to which to append members. Defaults to the class with the same name as the wrapped class - exclude: black-list of members which should not be copied
